head.title: Sothebyʼs Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts and Library, 1930

div.p: On 24 July 1930, Sotheby & Co. held an important sale of Ruskinʼs literary remains, described in the catalogueʼs title as the Manuscripts and Remaining Library of John Ruskin, Removed from His Residence, Brantwood, Coniston, and Sold with the Consent of Arthur Severn, Esq., and of His Trustees. This sale was perhaps the single most consequential event for the provenance of the early manuscripts.

The first 109 lots of the sale contained items from Ruskinʼs library, of which more than half (lots 24–83) was devoted to “The Kate Greenaway Collection from Brantwood”, while the remainder ranged from illuminated manuscripts and incunabula to modern first editions and presentation copies. As indicated by a copy of the catalogue at the Beinecke Library that was annotated by an observer during the sale, coveted items fetching high prices in this part of the sale included the Greenaway books and a copy of William Blakeʼs illustrated edition of Youngʼs Night Thoughts, its engravings “coloured by the artist himself”. Sothebyʼs must have anticipated that the Greenaway collection would command interest, having devoted four of the six plates in the illustrated catalogue to drawings from her books, as compared with only two plates showing Ruskin manuscripts. Still, as suggested by the final selling prices noted in the Beinecke copy of the catalogue, the Ruskin manuscripts reserved for the second half of the sale were considered the gems of the occasion. Whereas the highest prices in the first part of the sale included £400 for the Blake Night Thoughts and £420 for a collection autograph letters from Greenaway to Ruskin, prices for the Ruskin manuscripts ranged from £440 for the manuscript of The Stones of Venice, £520 for a collection of Ruskinʼs letters to his father, and £1,600 for Ruskinʼs diaries.

The Ruskin manuscript portion of the sale was advertised in the catalogue as the “Ruskin Manuscripts from Brantwood: A large and highly important collection of autograph letters, diaries, note-books, poems, etc., including the original manuscript notes and sketches for ‘The Stones of Venice’, ‘Fors Clavigera’, ‘Praeterita’, and numerous other works, extending from 1827 to the end of Ruskinʼs working life in 1889” (Sotheby & Co., Catalogue of the Manuscripts and Remaining Library of John Ruskin, 18). The sale was divided into lots 110–22, of which the following pertain to the contents of the ERM archive:

list.item: Lot 110, “Letters to His Father, John James Ruskin”, items 1–6 as numbered in the catalogue, each item consisting of a 4o blue‐morocco and gilt binding containing letters, 6 volumes in total. Item 1, the first volume, entitled in the catalogue as “Early Poems”, corresponds to MS XI. The catalogue description does not mention that W. G. Collingwood had assigned a roman‐numeral designation to this collection in “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems” (see Introductory Essay on Editing and Bibliography; and System of Title Citation for Manuscripts); and indeed, while Collingwoodʼs 1891 description of MS XI as an “envelope containing collected loose papers” had been updated in the Library Edition as “now [in 1903] bound up in a volume of letters and poems” (Ruskin, Works, 2:534), by 1930 even that description had become inaccurate, owing to rebinding (see MS XI: Description). That this first volume of the six in lot 110 includes the items in Collingwoodʼs “envelope” is clear, however, from the catalogue description of “Early Poems (8), beginning with ‘Look at that Ship’, dated Feb. or March, 1828, when Ruskin was nine years old”, along with 137 letters, 1829–59.

Lot 112, “Early Poems and Juvenilia”, items I–VI, each item consisting of a blue‐morocco slipcase, which contained manuscripts as follows. (The slipcases are not individually described in the catalogue, but they remain along with their original contents at the Beinecke Library. Starting in the 1990s, to guard against wear, the manuscripts were no longer stored inside the slipcases). As the catalogue acknowledges (p. 20), to describe the manuscripts, it relies on Collingwoodʼs “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems” in Poems (1891) (see Introductory Essay on Editing and Bibliography; and System of Title Citation for Manuscripts), citing Collingwoodʼs roman‐numeral designations for the respective manuscripts, and borrowing condensed versions of his descriptions of the contents (items I.1–3, 5; II–V). Only the sizes and physical descriptions use Sothebyʼs own, more exacting terms. It is noteworthy that, in context of rare‐book and manuscript dealing, Collingwoodʼs edition remained authoritative, and the Library Edition is not mentioned, although the latter documents items I.4 and VI, which Collingwoodʼs “Preliminary Note” omits. This is a sign, perhaps, that few scholars had mastered the vast detail of the Library Edition.
Item I, a slipcase, HARRY & LUCY | POEMS | &c, containing manuscripts 1–5 as numbered in the catalogue:
Item II, a slipcase, RUSKIN | MS. | POEMS | 1829–32 | 1902, containing MS V, half calf, 7.25 × 4.75 in.
Item III, a slipcase, RUSKIN | MS. | ITERIAD | &c | 1902, containing MS VII, half roan, 9.75 × 8 in.
Item IV, a slipcase, RUSKIN | MS. | POEMS | ETC. | 1831–38, containing MS VIII, half roan, 9.25 × 5.75 in.
Item V, a slipcase, RUSKIN | MS. | POEMS | 1833, containing MS IX, half roan, 8 × 6 in.

Item VI, a slipcase, RUSKIN | MS. | JUVENILIA, containing “three note books”. Given the existence of this slipcase at the time the catalogue was compiled, the three notebooks can be presumed to be the same as the manuscripts now associated with that slipcase in the Beinecke Library, as follows. As in item I.4 above, the catalogue does not draw on existing descriptions that were available in the Library Edition, although admittedly the reference is rather deeply buried in the bibliography volume (Ruskin, Works, 38:206). The catalogue describes the notebooks as a group: “74–84–84 pp. containing geological, historical and grammatical notes, half roan, 6 × 4 in.” This summary of the contents credibly, if only roughly, corresponds to the Latin grammar, mineralogy, travel itineraries, and sermon drafts in fact contained in these manuscripts. The material “half roan” is incorrect, however—the notebooks being full roan, like the Red Books in I.1–5, above—and the catalogueʼs page count of the notebooks only very roughly approximates the 44 leaves, 42 leaves, and 43 leaves respectively found in them, as follows. The catalogue may afford a clue, however, that a leaf now missing from the third of these notebooks was still attached at the time of the sale, since that possibility would account for the catalogueʼs identical “84–84 pp.” for two of the notebooks:
Lot 113, “ The Poetry of Architecture and Modern Painters”.
Lot 114, “The King of the Golden River”.

div.p: The manuscripts listed in lots 110, 112, and 114, as described in the catalogue with their slipcases and bindings, are now held by the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. When first acquired, these lots, in the eyes of the Yale curators, would have formed a unit tied together not only by their contents, which all relate to Ruskinʼs youth, but even by their blue‐morocco casings, which appear to be unique to these manuscripts. Whoever was originally responsible for this choice of bindings probably did perceive the manuscripts as forming a group, a perception likely founded in Collingwoodʼs bibliographical preparation for the Poems (1891) (see Provenance of Early Manuscripts at Denmark Hill and Brantwood.

While lots 110 112, and 114 ended up at Yale, the identity of their initial buyer, and the details of the manuscriptsʼ journey between London and New Haven, are obscured by conflicting evidence. Lot 112, containing the twelve “little notebooks”, was, according to Charles Beecher Hogan, “purchased by Mr. Charles Goodspeed”, the Boston book dealer, “en bloc at Sothebyʼs”, “and in turn purchased by Yale”. Hogan also notes that Yale acquired the King of the Golden River manuscript through Goodspeed. The volumes of letters, lot 110, however, Hogan says “were purchased by Yale at the Sotheby auction of July 24, 1930”, suggesting that Yale did not go through Goodspeed for these manuscripts (Hogan, “Yale Collection of the Manuscripts of John Ruskin”, 62, 65, 63). Curiously, in Goodspeedʼs memoir, the dealer acknowledges acquiring the manuscripts of The King of the Golden River, Praeterita (Lot 121), and a portion of Fors Clavigera (Lot 118) at the 1930 auction, but he fails to mention the letters and the Red Books. Goodspeed writes: Praeterita “I kept myself”, from this sale; “the others I sold”, he summarizes (Goodspeed, Yankee Bookseller, 267). If Hogan is correct, the “others” must have included Lot 112 containing the Red Books, as well, but Hogan is almost certainly incorrect about that lot coming to Yale through Goodspeed.

I have seen evidence at the Beinecke Library that, on 6 November 1930, Yale University Library acquired from Goodspeed eight items that had been auctioned three months earlier at the Sothebyʼs sale. The list, which confirms Goodspeedʼs comment in his memoir, includes The King of the Golden River, but not the juvenilia in lot 112.The other seven items invoiced to Yale are the manuscripts of Fors Clavigera (lot 118), Proserpina (lot 117), Oxford lectures (lot 116), lectures on the Val dʼArno (lot 116); 13 “miscellaneous notebooks”, grouped as lot 122, and an “architectural notebook” (lot 116); and Ruskinʼs set of the Botanical Magazine, with marginalia (lot 16). All these items, according to a copy of the Sothebyʼs catalogue at the Beinecke that was annotated during the sale, were sold to the firm of B. F. Stevens & Brown for a total of £188 (in the catalogue, the lot containing the magazine set is not glossed, but it did go to Stevens & Brown according to Dearden, Ruskin, Bembridge, and Brantwood, 48). The King of the Golden River manuscript cost this buyer almost as much as the rest, at £155. Goodspeed turned all this around to Yale for $3,000—throwing in, apparently as a kind of bonus, a collection of 47 autograph Ruskin letters, chiefly to Benjamin Jowett. The latter had no connection to the Sotheby sale that is detectable in the catalogue. These items acquired by Yale in November were sold at auction, according to the annotated sale catalogue at the Beinecke, to “Stevens B. F.” This is the firm of B. F. Stevens & Brown. Goodspeed mentions that this firm served as his agent in the 1931 sales (Goodspeed, Yankee Bookseller, 268), and the Beinecke holds correspondence between the proprietor, Ralph Brown, and Goodspeed starting in that year; as the evidence shows, however, the relationship reached back farther to the 1930 sale, if not earlier.

It was only a few years earlier, in 1927, that Ralph Brown had established what would prove a thirty‐year relationship with the important English Ruskin collector, J. H. Whitehouse (Dearden, Ruskin, Bembridge, and Brantwood, 43–44). In 1930, Whitehouse himself attended the Sothebyʼs sale and bid in his own name (Dearden, Ruskin, Bembridge, and Brantwood, 49), and so Stevens & Brown would have been free to work on commission for Goodspeed, if such was the arrangement. While there was doubtless rivalry between Goodspeed, Whitehouse, and other collectors, however, B. F. Stevens & Brown appears to have been bound to them by respect for Ruskin. A key figure in these relationships was Hugh Allen, who, on his death in August 1931, Brown remembered to Goodspeed as “our friend” and “a sad loss to Ruskin lovers as his knowledge and kindly interest was always at the disposal of those, who like himself, admired the great Victorian” (AL, Brown to Goodspeed, 29 August 1931).

It was probably Hugh Allen who acquired lot 112, the juvenilia, at the 1930 sale. According to the annotated sale catalogue at the Beinecke, the successful bid was place by “Allen” for £260, who also acquired lot 110 (the letters) for £520. Allenʼs part in the 1930–31 Sothebyʼs sales can be gathered from a letter by Ralph Brown to J. H. Whitehouse, on the occasion of the Severn Sale of Ruskin Effects, 1931: “we are having the benefit of the assistance of our friend Mr. Hugh Allen, and his help has been invaluable”, as compared with “the lack of interest shown by the Severn family in all matters pertaining to Ruskin” (quoted in Dearden, Ruskin, Bembridge, and Brantwood, 87). Thus, while there is no evidence supporting Hoganʼs claim that Yale bought lot 112,The provenance of lot 112 is not Hoganʼs only error; he also declares that the Proserpina manuscript and studies “were sold at Sothebyʼs on May 18, 1931, and came to Yale by purchase from Mr. Goodspeed” (Hogan, “Yale Collection of the Manuscripts of John Ruskin”, 67 n. 4). A part of this manuscript did come from the Sothebyʼs Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts, 1931 via Goodspeed, but the holding started with lot 117 from the 1930 sale, as explained above. the Red Books, from Goodspeed, it is possible that Goodspeed served as a conduit between Yale and Allen, in supplying the university library with both lots 112 and 110 from the Sothebyʼs sale. Whatever Goodspeedʼs involvement, if any, the lots came to Yale from Allen as a unit, as they are treated together in the earliest published report on Yaleʼs acquisitions from the July 1930 sale. Appearing in January 1931, the report treats the juvenilia along with the letters as a single “collection” (Weihe, “A Collection of Ruskin Manuscripts”). What remains enigmatic is that this published report makes no mention of the several items, including the King of the Golden River manuscript, which Goodspeed certainly did sell to the library the previous November.

Whomever or whatever interest Allen represented, his expenditure on lots 110 and 112 was significant, attesting to the value placed on these early manuscripts, presumably for their biographical interest. At £520, the letters fetched the second highest price of the manuscript lots after the £1,600 for the diaries, higher even than the £440 paid for the Stones of Venice materials. The £260 for the Red Books was significantly more than what B. F. Stevens paid for the King of the Golden River and the Praeterita manuscripts, at £155 and £166, respectively. Insofar as prices serve as a measure, manuscripts related to Ruskinʼs youth that the author referenced in the autobiography were valued more than the manuscript of the autobiography itself. (Goodspeed clung to the Praeterita manuscript, and treasured it, however; and it is interesting that, while prices for the late works were, not surprisingly, comparatively low, Hoganʼs 1942 article treated “the possession of the manuscripts of the Fors Clavigera and the Praeterita” as what “makes the Yale collection truly rich” [Hogan, “Yale Collection of the Manuscripts of John Ruskin”, 68].) It is possible, moreover, that the comparatively high prices for the early manuscripts was the effect not only of the interest in Ruskinʼs youth that the author himself had encouraged through his autobiographical writing, but also of the broader phenomenon of The Collecting of Modern Authors in the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries.
